question: Consider the following statements:
Statement(I): The set of all solutions of the linear inequalities <katex>$3x+8<17$</katex> and <katex>$2x+8\ge12$</katex> are <katex>$x<3$</katex> and <katex>$x\ge2$</katex> respectively.
Statement(II): The common set of solutions of linear inequalities <katex>$3x+8<17$</katex> and <katex>$2x+8\ge12$</katex> is (2, 3)
Which of the following is true?
choices: Statement (I) is true but statement (II) is false
Statement (I) is false but statement (II) is true
explanation: The common solution is the intersection of <katex>$x < 3$</katex> and <katex>$x \ge 2$</katex>, which is <katex>$[2, 3)$</katex> or <katex>$\{x: 2 \le x < 3\}$</katex>.

Statement (II) claims the solution is <katex>$(2, 3)$</katex> (open interval) or a set <katex>$\{2, 3\}$</katex>. Mathematically, the correct interval is <katex>$[2, 3)$</katex>. The statement says "(2, 3)" which excludes 2, making it false. Or if it implies discrete integer solutions, it might be {2}. Given the options and typical precision, Statement II is considered false because it misses the boundary condition or is just the integers.
